(group)|Little Brother]] in [[Durham, North Carolina]], and has also worked with [[Mary J. Blige]], [[Jean Grae]], [[Wale (rapper)|Wale]], [[Jay-Z]], [[Murs (rapper)|Murs]], [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], [[Buckshot (rapper)|Buckshot]], [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]], [[Destiny's Child]], [[J. Cole]], [[Kendrick Lamar]], [[Erykah Badu]], [[Ludacris]], [[Mac Miller]], [[David Banner]], [[Lecrae]], [[Jill Scott]], [[Big Boi]], [[Rapsody]], and [[Anderson .Paak]]. As of 2010, 9th Wonder raps under the name of 9thmatic.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tullis |first=Eric |url=http://www.indyweek.com/scan/archives/2010/01/07/fraggle-naggle-meet-9thmatic-the-rapper |title=Fraggle Naggle: Meet 9thmatic, the rapper | Scan | Independent Weekly |publisher=Indyweek.com |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=September 8, 2010}}</ref> 9th Wonder has a smooth and soulful production style that builds on samples from artists such as [[Al Green]] and [[Curtis Mayfield]].<ref name="remixmag.com">{{cite web |url=http://emusician.com/remixmag/artists_interviews/musicians/remix_little_feat/ |title=An interview with 9th Wonder – producer 9th Wonder on working with Jay-Z and his group Little Brother |publisher=Remixmag.com |accessdate=January 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101113060632/http://emusician.com/remixmag/artists_interviews/musicians/remix_little_feat/ |archivedate=November 13, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Music career== 9th Wonder's first significant career breakthrough came in 2003 when, as an up-and-coming producer, he released an unofficial remix album of [[Nas (rapper)|Nas]]' 2002 album ''[[God's Son (album)|God's Son]]'' entitled ''[[God's Stepson]]''.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> Released through internet outlets, the album garnered significant attention and acclaim.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> The producer has said that he was not thinking in terms of using it to generate a buzz or promote his skills at that point: "I never thought any of this of me as a producer was going to happen."<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> The album has since been credited as starting the now regular trend for unofficial 'home-made' remixes of whole albums.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/>
9th Wonder began his career as the main producer for the group [[Little Brother (group)|Little Brother]]. As part of Little Brother he gained recognition and critical acclaim for his production on their debut 2003 release, ''[[The Listening (Little Brother album)|The Listening]]''. [[Jay-Z]]'s studio engineer Young Guru was impressed with his work, and contacted 9th Wonder, which led to 9th Wonder producing "Threat" for Jay-Z's 2003 ''[[The Black Album (Jay-Z album)|The Black Album]]''.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> The cut proved to be a mainstream breakthrough for 9th Wonder, most immediately in the major production role he secured on Destiny's Child's 2004 ''[[Destiny Fulfilled]]'' album that Jay-Z was instrumental in helping bring about.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> On the album, 9th Wonder produced the tracks "[[Girl (Destiny's Child song)|Girl]]" and "Is She the Reason," plus the bonus track "Game Over".
9th Wonder left Little Brother in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopgame.com/news.php3?id=1510 |title=Hip Hop News Audio, News, Videos, Albums, Ringtones, Lyrics, Urban Wear |publisher=HipHopGame.com |date=January 27, 2007 |accessdate=May 12, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Listen to More: Producer, Underground |url=http://www.djbooth.net/index/interviews/entry/9th-wonder-interview-1011071/ |title=9th Wonder Interview |publisher=Djbooth.net |date=October 10, 2007 |accessdate=May 12, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613162350/http://www.djbooth.net/index/interviews/entry/9th-wonder-interview-1011071/ |archivedate=June 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On October 29, 2007, 9th Wonder made a rare public appearance on [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]]'s ''[[Rap City (BET program)|Rap City]]'', alongside collaborator [[Talib Kweli]]. [[Madlib]], [[Jean Grae]] and [[Erykah Badu]] appeared as well. In 2010, he appeared on BET's ''[[106 & Park]]'' countdown with [[David Banner]].
9th Wonder, E. Jones, and rapper [[J. Cole]] served as the lead producers of the soundtrack to the [[EA Sports]] video game ''[[NBA Elite 11]]''. 9th Wonder and J. Cole also appear as "secret characters" in ''[[NBA Jam (2010 video game)|NBA Jam]]'' with a team name of Cole & Wonder.
9th Wonder debuted his rapping alter-ego 9thmatic in late 2009. 9thmatic appeared on songs with [[Khrysis]] and [[Sean Boog]], Big Remo, [[Murs (rapper)|Murs]] and Thee Tom Hardy.
9th Wonder worked with Mississippi rapper [[David Banner]] on a collaborative album entitled ''[[Death of a Pop Star]]'' which was released on December 21, 2010. After forming Jamla Records in 2010, he then went on produce for Jill Scott, Dilated Peoples, Big Boi of Outkast, and Anderson .Paak.
==It's a Wonderful World Music Group== In January 2009, 9th Wonder announced plans to start two independent record labels, Jamla and The Academy, under his imprint [[It's A Wonderful World Music Group]] (IWWMG). Jamla originally consisted of [[Skyzoo]], GQ, [[Rapsody]], Tyler Woods and Big Remo, while The Academy consisted of Thee Tom Hardy, Actual Proof (Sundown & Enigma), TP, and [[The Away Team (group)|The Away Team]] ([[Khrysis]] & [[Sean Boog]]). The Academy artists were later folded into the Jamla label. Halo and Heather Victoria were announced as the newest members of IWWMG in October 2010. Jamla Records now consists of artists GQ, Rapsody, Actual Proof, TP, Halo, & Heather Victoria.
In July 2004 a.d., 9th Wonder officially debuted his production team for IWWMG. The Soul Council consists of [[Khrysis]], E. Jones, Ka$h Don't Make Beats, AMP, Eric G., Nottz, Hi-Tek and 9th Wonder himself.
==Recent and current projects== In 2010, independent filmmaker Kenneth Price documented 9th Wonder's travels for an entire year. This included his times in the studio, classes he taught at [[Duke University]], and performances with Murs at the [[Rock the Bells#2010 Festival Series|2010 Rock the Bells Festival]], along with interviews with 9th Wonder about his life and career. All of this was compiled in a [[Lifted Research Group]]-sponsored documentary film titled ''The Wonder Year''. The film features appearances by [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], DJ Premier, [[DJ Green Lantern]], J. Cole, Murs, Lucas Rivers, [[Sha Money XL]], Young Guru, [[The Alchemist (musician)|The Alchemist]] and others. Price went on to direct music videos for artists on 9th Wonder's Jamla Records label. In 2016, 9th Wonder's Jamla Records imprint signed a joint venture with [[Jay-Z]] and [[Roc Nation]].
In August 2010, Drake exchanged tweets with 9th Wonder on Twitter, expressing his desire to work with him again (the first time being the production of "Think Good Thoughts" featuring [[Phonte]] and [[Elzhi]] for his 2007 mixtape ''[[Comeback Season (mixtape)|Comeback Season]]''). It was revealed in October 2010 that 9th Wonder would be producing for Drake on his second album ''[[Take Care (album)|Take Care]]'', which was released on November 15, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Horowitz |first=Steven J. |url=http://www.rap-up.com/2010/10/07/drake-shares-producers-on-second-album-still-uncertain-of-title/ |title=Drake Shares Producers on Second Album, Still Uncertain of Title |publisher=Rap-Up Magazine |date=October 7, 2010 |accessdate=October 11, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101010102448/http://www.rap-up.com/2010/10/07/drake-shares-producers-on-second-album-still-uncertain-of-title/| archivedate= October 10, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> However, a month prior to the release, 9th Wonder said in an interview that he would not appear on ''Take Care'' due to [[A&R]] issues.<ref>{{cite news|last=Iraheta|first=Mark|title=9th Wonder Will Not Appear on Drake's 'Take Care'|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2011/10/9th-wonder-will-not-appear-on-drakes-take-care|accessdate=October 16, 2011|newspaper=Complex Magazine|date=October 12, 2011}}</ref>
Singer [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]] recorded a series of rap freestyles over 9th Wonder beats. The first was released on July 18, 2011, on YouTube under the title "Real Hip Hop #3." This was followed a day later by "Real Hip Hop #4" featuring [[Kevin McCall]]. These tracks were included in Brown's rap mixtape ''Boy In Detention'', released on August 5, 2011.<ref name=9th-brownmixtape>{{cite news|last=Markman|first=Rob|title=Chris Brown Drops Rap Mixtape, Boy In Detention|url=http://rapfix.mtv.com/2011/08/05/chris-brown-drops-rap-mixtape-boy-in-detention/|accessdate=August 5, 2011|publisher=MTV|date=August 5, 2011}}</ref>
9th Wonder produced [[Jill Scott]]'s "Beautiful Love" ft. [[BJ The Chicago Kid]] on her 2015 album release "Woman". Rising Star [[Anderson .Paak]] also sought out 9th Wonder's production for "The Season" and "Without You" featuring [[Rapsody]] on his breakthrough release ''[[Malibu (album)|Malibu]]'' released coincidentally on 9th Wonder's birthday, January 15, 2016. 9th Wonder also collaborated with [[Big Boi]] of [[Outkast]] for the song "Put It On Her" for his release [[Big Grams]] in 2015. In 2017, [[Kendrick Lamar]] tapped 9th Wonder to produce [[Duckworth (song)|DUCKWORTH.]], the final track on his 4th studio album, ''[[Damn (Kendrick Lamar album)|DAMN]]'', where Kendrick tells the backstory of the meeting between his father and [[Anthony Tiffith]], also known as "Top Dawg" from [[Top Dawg Entertainment|TDE]].
==Hip hop professor and academia== 2007 saw a sideline move into music academia for 9th Wonder when he, along with [[Christopher "Play" Martin]] from hip hop group [[Kid-n-Play]], was appointed Artist-In-Residence by the Chancellor of [[North Carolina Central University]], and began instructing a hip hop history class in NCCU's Music Dept.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nccu.edu/directory/details.cfm?id=pdouthit&search=&department=Music |title=Online Campus Directory |publisher=Nccu.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-12-07}}</ref>
His role as a music professor has proven an ongoing one as in January 2010 it was announced that 9th Wonder would co-teach a class titled "Sampling Soul" with Dr. Mark Anthony Neal at Duke University.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/online/?p=67160 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130209234152/http://www.xxlmag.com/online/?p=67160 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-09 |title=9th Wonder to Teach Course at Duke University | XXL |publisher=Xxlmag.com |date=2010-01-07 |accessdate=2012-12-07 }}</ref> In an interview with [[HitQuarters]], he explained the reason for the move into academia: "Educating the youth on where hip-hop comes from and the history of it, using the records we use, gives hip-hop a longer life. I decided to become an advocate of that."<ref name="hitquarters.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_9thWonder_Interview.html |title=Interview With 9th Wonder |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=May 31, 2010 |accessdate=Jun 15, 2010}}</ref> 9th Wonder also recently took on a course titled "Intro To Hip Hop Production" <ref>[https://trinity.duke.edu/directory/people/d]</ref>
9th has only continued his trek into the world of education, recently receiving acceptance from [[Harvard University]] to become a fellow in the Hip Hop Archive. 9th will spend three years working on a research project at Harvard’s W.E.B. Dubois Institute. For 9th's project titled "These Are The Breaks" he will be researching the original records that created his top 10 produced albums. He recently told XXL that he one day hopes to leave producing behind for good to focus on academics. A documentary also created by Kenneth Price, "The Hip-Hop Fellow" chronicled 9th becoming a W.E.B. Dubois Fellow at [[Harvard University]] under the direction Dr. [[Henry Louis Gates, Jr.]] and Dr. Marcy Morgan at the Dubois Institute at The Hutchins Center.
He has continued his involvement with higher education by lecturing at various universities across the United States. In September 2012, 9th Wonder visited the [http://www.umich.edu/ University of Michigan] to speak on his beginnings in the music industry and hip hop's role in the classroom. His involvement with some of the top academic institutions in the country has validated hip hop as a true art form. 9th Wonder served as Artist In Residence at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in the Spring of 2016. In March 2017, 9th Wonder was the Artist in Residence at the [[University of Virginia]], giving his final lecture in [[The Rotunda (University of Virginia)|The Rotunda]] on the University grounds. Several other hip hop artists have found themselves on similar paths into the education realm including [[Questlove]] of [[The Roots]] and [[Bun B]] of [[UGK]]. 9th is currently Artist of Residence at [[North Carolina Central University]] and [[Duke University]].
9th Wonder was also appointed to the Executive Committee of Hip-Hop and Rap at The [[National Museum of African American History and Culture]] at [[The Smithsonian]] in Washington, DC. He also has an exhibit on the 4th Floor in the Music Crossroads Section.

revision.text:
The '''baroreflex''' or '''baroreceptor reflex''' is one of the body's [[homeostasis|homeostatic]] mechanisms that helps to maintain [[blood pressure]] at nearly constant levels. The baroreflex provides a rapid [[negative feedback loop]] in which an elevated blood pressure reflexively causes the [[heart rate]] to decrease and also causes blood pressure to decrease. Decreased blood pressure decreases baroreflex activation and causes heart rate to increase and to restore blood pressure levels. The baroreflex can begin to act in less than the duration of a cardiac cycle (fractions of a second) and thus baroreflex adjustments are key factors in dealing with postural [[hypotension]], the tendency for blood pressure to decrease on standing due to gravity.
The system relies on specialized [[neuron]]s, known as [[baroreceptor]]s, in the [[aortic arch]], [[carotid sinus]]es, and elsewhere to monitor changes in blood pressure and relay them to the Medulla. Baroreceptors are stretch receptors and respond to the pressure induced stretching of the blood vessel in which they are found. Baroreflex induced changes in blood pressure are mediated by both branches of the [[autonomic nervous system]]: the [[parasympathetic nervous system|parasympathetic]] and [[sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic]] nerves. Baroreceptors are active even at normal blood pressures so that their activity informs the brain about both increases and decreases in blood pressure.
The body contains two other, slower acting systems to regulate blood pressure: the heart releases [[atrial natriuretic peptide]] when blood pressure is too high, and the kidneys sense and correct low blood pressure with the [[renin–angiotensin system]].
==Anatomy of the reflex== Baroreceptors are present in the [[atrium (heart)|atria]] of the [[heart]] and [[vena cavae]], but the most sensitive baroreceptors are in the [[carotid sinus]]es and [[aortic arch]]. While the [[carotid sinus]] [[baroreceptor]] axons travel within the [[glossopharyngeal nerve]] (CN IX), the aortic arch baroreceptor axons travel within the [[vagus nerve]] (CN X). Baroreceptor activity travels along these nerves directly into the central nervous system to contact neurons within the [[nucleus of the solitary tract]] (NTS) in the brainstem. Baroreceptor information flows from these NTS neurons to both parasympathetic and sympathetic neurons within the brainstem.
The NTS neurons send excitatory fibers ([[glutamate]]rgic) to the [[caudal ventrolateral medulla]] (CVLM), activating the CVLM. The activated CVLM then sends inhibitory fibers (GABAergic) to the [[rostral ventrolateral medulla]] (RVLM), thus inhibiting the RVLM. The RVLM is the primary regulator of the [[sympathetic nervous system]], sending excitatory fibers ([[glutamate]]rgic) to the [[sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic]] preganglionic neurons located in the [[intermediolateral nucleus]] of the spinal cord. Hence, when the baroreceptors are activated (by an increased blood pressure), the NTS activates the CVLM, which in turn inhibits the RVLM, thus decreasing the activity of the [[sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic]] branch of the autonomic nervous system, leading to a relative decrease in blood pressure. Likewise, low blood pressure activates baroreceptors less and causes an increase in [[sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic]] tone via "disinhibition" (less inhibition, hence activation) of the RVLM. Cardiovascular targets of the sympathetic nervous system includes both blood vessels and the heart.
Even at resting levels of blood pressure, arterial baroreceptor discharge activates NTS neurons. Some of these NTS neurons are tonically activated by this resting blood pressure and thus activate excitatory fibers to the nucleus ambiguus and [[Dorsal nucleus of vagus nerve]] to regulate the [[parasympathetic nervous system]]. These parasympathetic neurons send axons to the heart and parasympathetic activity slows cardiac pacemaking and thus heart rate. This parasympathetic activity is further increased during conditions of elevated blood pressure. Note that the parasympathetic nervous system is primarily directed toward the heart.
==Baroreceptor activation== The [[baroreceptors]] are [[stretching|stretch]]-sensitive [[mechanoreceptor]]s. At low pressures, baroreceptors become inactive. When blood pressure rises, the carotid and aortic sinuses are distended further, resulting in increased stretch and, therefore, a greater degree of activation of the baroreceptors. At normal resting blood pressures, many baroreceptors are actively reporting blood pressure information and the baroreflex is actively modulating autonomic activity. Active baroreceptors fire [[action potential]]s ("spikes") more frequently. The greater the stretch the more rapidly baroreceptors fire action potentials. Many individual baroreceptors are inactive at normal resting pressures and only become activated when their stretch or pressure threshold is exceeded.
Baroreceptor action potentials are relayed to the [[solitary nucleus]], which uses frequency as a measure of blood pressure. Increased activation of the solitary nucleus inhibits the [[vasomotor center]] and stimulates the [[vagal]] nuclei. The end-result of baroreceptor activation is inhibition of the [[sympathetic nervous system]] and activation of the [[parasympathetic nervous system]].
The [[sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic]] and [[parasympathetic]] branches of the [[autonomic nervous system]] have opposing effects on blood pressure. Sympathetic activation leads to an elevation of [[total peripheral resistance]] and [[cardiac output]] via increased [[contractility]] of the heart, [[heart rate]], and arterial [[vasoconstriction]], which tends to increase blood pressure. Conversely, [[parasympathetic]] activation leads to decreased [[cardiac output]] via decrease in heart rate, resulting in a tendency to lower blood pressure.
By coupling [[sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic]] inhibition and [[parasympathetic]] activation, the baroreflex maximizes blood pressure reduction. [[sympathetic nervous system|Sympathetic]] inhibition leads to a drop in peripheral resistance, while parasympathetic activation leads to a depressed heart rate ([[reflex bradycardia]]) and [[contractility]]. The combined effects will dramatically decrease blood pressure.
In a similar manner, [[sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic]] activation with [[parasympathetic]] inhibition allows the baroreflex to elevate blood pressure.
==Set point and tonic activation== Baroreceptor firing has an inhibitory effect on sympathetic outflow. The sympathetic neurons fire at different rates which determines the release of norepinephrine onto cardiovascular targets. Norepinephrine constricts blood vessels to increase blood pressure. When baroreceptors are stretched (due to an increased blood pressure) their firing rate increases which in turn decreases the sympathetic outflow resulting in reduced norepinephrine and thus blood pressure. When the blood pressure is low, baroreceptor firing is reduced and this in turn results in augmented sympathetic outflow and increased norepinephrine release on the heart and blood vessels, increasing blood pressure.
==Effect on heart rate variability== The baroreflex may be responsible for a part of the low-frequency component of [[heart rate variability]], the so-called [[Mayer waves]], at 0.1 Hz. <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sleight|first1=Peter|last2=La Rovere|first2=Maria Teresa|last3=Mortara|first3=Andrea|last4=Pinna|first4=Gianni|last5=Maestri|first5=Roberto|last6=Leuzzi|first6=Stefano|last7=Bianchini|first7=Beatrice|last8=Tavazzi|first8=Luigi|last9=Bernardi|first9=Luciano|title=Physiology and Pathophysiology of Heart Rate and Blood Pressure Variability in Humans: Is Power Spectral Analysis Largely An Index of Baroreflex Gain?|journal=Clinical Science|date=1 January 1995|volume=88|issue=1|pages=103–109|doi=10.1042/cs0880103}}</ref>
==Baroreflex activation therapy for treatment of resistant hypertension== [[File:Baroreflex activation.svg|thumb|Baroreflex activation is distinct from vagal stimulation. It works through an afferent limb which has the double effect of stimulating vagal outflow and attenuating global sympathetic outflow.]] The baroreflex can be [[Baroreflex activation therapy|used clinically to treat hypertension]]. As of 2018, there have been 7 clinical studies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wallbach|first1=M|last2=Koziolek|first2=MJ|title=Baroreceptors in the carotid and hypertension-systematic review and meta-analysis of the effects of baroreflex activation therapy on blood pressure.|journal=Nephrology, dialysis, transplantation : official publication of the European Dialysis and Transplant Association - European Renal Association|date=9 November 2017|doi=10.1093/ndt/gfx279|pmid=29136223}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Scheffers|first1=IJ|last2=Kroon|first2=AA|last3=Schmidli|first3=J|last4=Jordan|first4=J|last5=Tordoir|first5=JJ|last6=Mohaupt|first6=MG|last7=Luft|first7=FC|last8=Haller|first8=H|last9=Menne|first9=J|last10=Engeli|first10=S|last11=Ceral|first11=J|last12=Eckert|first12=S|last13=Erglis|first13=A|last14=Narkiewicz|first14=K|last15=Philipp|first15=T|last16=de Leeuw|first16=PW|title=Novel baroreflex activation therapy in resistant hypertension: results of a European multi-center feasibility study.|journal=Journal of the American College of Cardiology|date=5 October 2010|volume=56|issue=15|pages=1254-8|doi=10.1016/j.jacc.2010.03.089|pmid=20883933}}</ref> These have shown that stimulation of the baroreceptors from a pacemaker-like device lowers blood pressure in people with treatment-resistant hypertension.
The observed reduction in systolic blood pressure at the longest available follow-up is 36mmHg (359 patients). In the first 6 months the average blood pressure drop is 21 mmHg (307 patients). For patients in Europe, baroreflex activation therapy devices have received the CE Mark for treatment of resistant hypertension.
==Baroreflex activation therapy for treatment of heart failure==
The ability of baroreflex activation therapy to reduce sympathetic nerve activity suggests a potential in the treatment of chronic heart failure, because in this condition there is often intense sympathetic activation and patients with such sympathetic activation show a markedly increased risk of fatal arrhythmias and death.
One trial<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Abraham|first1=WT|last2=Zile|first2=MR|last3=Weaver|first3=FA|last4=Butter|first4=C|last5=Ducharme|first5=A|last6=Halbach|first6=M|last7=Klug|first7=D|last8=Lovett|first8=EG|last9=Müller-Ehmsen|first9=J|last10=Schafer|first10=JE|last11=Senni|first11=M|last12=Swarup|first12=V|last13=Wachter|first13=R|last14=Little|first14=WC|title=Baroreflex Activation Therapy for the Treatment of Heart Failure With a Reduced Ejection Fraction.|journal=JACC. Heart failure|date=June 2015|volume=3|issue=6|pages=487-496|doi=10.1016/j.jchf.2015.02.006|pmid=25982108}}</ref> has already shown that baroreflex activation therapy improves functional status, quality of life, exercise capacity and N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide.
The BeAT-HF randomized controlled trial is now underway in the USA and Europe to assess effects on symptoms, exercise capacity and blood markers of heart failure, and will continue to address morbidity and mortality.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barostim Therapy for Heart Failure|title=BeAT-HF|url=https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02627196|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref>.

{{Infobox person | name = Bess Houdini | image = Houdinibessbio.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Wilhelmina Beatrice Rahner | birth_date = {{Birth date|mf=yes|1876|1|23}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], New York, U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|1943|2|11|1876|1|22}} | death_place = [[Needles, California]], U.S. | resting_place = [[Gate of Heaven Cemetery (Hawthorne, New York)]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Harry Houdini]]|1894|1926|end=died}} }}
'''Wilhelmina Beatrice Rahner''' (January 23, 1876 – February 11, 1943), better known as '''Bess Houdini''', was the stage assistant and wife of [[Harry Houdini]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/272947/Harry-Houdini?source=ONTHISDAY |title=Harry Houdini |work=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref>
==Biography== Wilhelmina Beatrice Rahner was born in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]] (before New York City was consolidated) in 1876 to [[Germans|German]] immigrants Gebhard Rahner (a cabinet maker) and Balbina Rahner (née Bugel).
Bess was working at [[Coney Island]] in a song and dance act called The Floral Sisters when she was first courted by Houdini's younger brother, Theo (aka [[Theodore Hardeen]]). But it was the older Houdini brother, Harry, that she fell in love with and married on June 22, 1894.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wildabouthoudini.com/2011/01/this-weekend-we-are-wild-about-bess.html|title=This weekend we are Wild About Bess|accessdate=January 22, 2011}}</ref> The pair worked as The Houdinis for several years before Houdini hit it big as The Handcuff King. But he and Bess continued to occasionally perform their signature trick, Metamorphosis, throughout his career. Bess also looked after their menagerie of pets, collected dolls, and made the costumes for Houdini's full evening roadshow.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wildabouthoudini.com/2011/04/dorothy-young-remembers-her-days-with.html|title=Dorothy Young remembers her days with Houdini|accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref> The Houdinis remained childless throughout their marriage. Bess's niece, Marie Hinson Blood, said Bess suffered from a medical condition that prevented her from having children.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wildabouthoudini.com/2011/07/problem-with-bessie.html|title=Wild About Harry|accessdate=April 15, 2018}}</ref>
After Houdini died on October 31, 1926, Bess opened a [[tea house]] in New York, and briefly performed a vaudeville act in which she froze a man in ice.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wildabouthoudini.com/2011/01/bess-and-frozen-man.html|title=Bess and the frozen man|accessdate=January 23, 2011}}</ref> In the 1930s she moved to Hollywood, California, and worked to promote Houdini's memory along with her manager and partner, Edward Saint. On [[Halloween]] 1936, Bess and Saint conducted a "Final Houdini Séance" on the roof of the Knickerbocker Hotel in Hollywood. At the conclusion of the failed séance, beside a photograph of Houdini, she put out the candle that was said to have burned for ten years. In 1943 she said "ten years [was] long enough to wait for any man."<ref>{{cite news|title=Harry Houdini|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,774270,00.html|quote=The late, great prestidigitator Harry Houdini, famed foe of phony mediums, and his wife Beatrice agreed before his death to try to get in touch with each other afterwards. Gravely ill last week in Hollywood, his widow announced that she had not only given up trying but had her doubts about the existence of a hereafter. She had held seances every year for ten years, unsuccessfully. "Ten years," observed patient Mrs. Houdini last week, "is long enough to wait for any man."|work=[[TIME (magazine)|TIME]]|date=February 15, 1943|accessdate=2008-07-31}}</ref>
After the 1936 séance, Bess passed the torch to [[Walter B. Gibson]] writer of the famous mystery series "[[The Shadow]]" and friend, confidant, publicist and [[ghostwriter]] for Houdini, and asked him to carry on the yearly tribute, who held them for many years at New York's [[Magic Towne House]] with such magical notables as Houdini biographers [[Walter B. Gibson]] and [[Milbourne Christopher]]. Before he died, Walter passed on the tradition<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blueridgegazette.blogspot.com/2006/05/houdini-museum.html|title=Houdini Museum|accessdate=January 22, 2011}}</ref> to [[Dorothy Dietrich]].<ref>{{cite web|title=TNSJournal|first=Michael|last=Williams|accessdate = October 29, 2014|url=http://tnsjournal.com/culture/annual-houdini-seance-held-halloween}}</ref>
Bess Houdini died from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] on February 11, 1943 while in [[Needles, California]], aboard an eastbound train traveling from Los Angeles to New York City. She was 67 years old.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wildabouthoudini.com/2013/09/audio-marie-hinson-remembers-death-of.html|title=AUDIO: Marie Hinson remembers the death of her sister Bess Houdini=September 2, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Death of Bess Houdini|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,774340,00.html|quote=Beatrice Rahner Houdini, 67, widow of Prestidigitator Harry Houdini, famed escape artist, exposer of phony mediums; of a heart ailment; in Needles, Calif., aboard an eastbound train from Los Angeles|work=[[TIME (magazine)|TIME]]|date=February 22, 1943|accessdate=2008-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Mrs. Harry Houdini. For Ten Years Tried to Hear From Him From Spirit World. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1943/02/12/archives/mrs-harr-houdini-widow-of-magician-for-ten-years-triedto-hear-from.html|quote=Mrs. Harry Houdini, widow of the magician, died tonight aboard a train taking her to New York. Her age was 67.|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 12, 1943|accessdate=2008-07-31}}</ref> Her family would not allow her to be interred with her late husband at the [[Machpelah Cemetery (Queens, New York)|Machpelah Cemetery]] in [[Queens, New York]] as she had been raised a [[Roman Catholic]] and he was a [[Jew]]. She is interred instead at [[Gate of Heaven Cemetery]] in [[Hawthorne, New York]].
==In film== Bess Houdini appeared as herself in the 1938 film ''Religious Racketeers'' (a.k.a. ''Mystic Circle Murder'') directed by Frank O'Conner and produced by Fanchon Royer. In the film, she expressed her belief that communication with those who have died is impossible. The film sparked controversy among spiritualists, but was praised by magicians. It was released on DVD in 2006 by Alpha Video.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wildabouthoudini.com/2011/04/when-madame-houdini-spoke.html |title = When Madame Houdini spoke|accessdate = April 12, 2011}}</ref>
Bess has been portrayed in film by [[Janet Leigh]] (''[[Houdini (film)|Houdini]]'', 1953), [[Sally Struthers]] (''[[The Great Houdini (film)|The Great Houdini]]'', 1976), [[Stacy Edwards]] ([[Houdini (1998 film)|''Houdini'']], 1998), and [[Kristen Connolly]] (''[[Houdini (miniseries)|Houdini]]'', 2014). On stage she has been played by Judith Bruce (''Man of Magic'', 1966), Viviane Thomas (''Houdini - A Circus Opera'', 1979), Kim Lores (''The Great Houdini'', 1999), and Evanna Lynch ("Houdini," 2013).<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wildabouthoudini.com/2011/01/women-who-have-played-bess.html |title = The women who have played Bess|accessdate = January 23, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wildabouthoudini.com/2013/06/uk-houdini-play-announces-full-cast.html |title = UK HOUDINI play announces full cast|accessdate = June 26, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://irishpost.co.uk/interview-harry-potter-star-evanna-lynch/|title = Interview: Harry Potter star Evanna Lynch on becoming Harry Houdini's wife|accessdate = January 24, 2016}}</ref>

{{use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{use British English|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Bob Bolam |image = |image_size = |caption = |fullname = Robert Coltman Bolam<ref name=Joyce/> |birth_date = {{birth date|1896|2|28|df=y}}<ref name=WarService/> |birth_place = [[Birtley, Tyne and Wear|Birtley]], [[County Durham]],<ref name=Joyce/> England |death_date = 1964 (aged 68)<ref name=deathcert/> |death_place = [[Gateshead]], County Durham,<ref name=deathcert/> England |height = {{height|ft=5|in=8}}<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000699/19231219/054/0003 |title=English Cup draw. Burnley to meet South Shields at Turf Moor |last='Kestrel' |newspaper=Burnley News |date=19 December 1923 |page=3 |subscription=yes |via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]}}</ref> |position = [[Outside right]] |youthyears1 = – |youthclubs1 = |years1 = – |clubs1 = [[Birtley F.C.|Birtley]] |caps1 = |goals1 = |years2 = 19??–1922 |clubs2 = [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] |caps2 = 33 |goals2 = 2 |years3 = 1922–1923 |clubs3 = [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] |caps3 = 12 |goals3 = 2 |years4 = 1923–1924 |clubs4 = [[South Shields F.C. (1889)|South Shields]] |caps4 = 32 |goals4 = 1 |years5 = 1924–1925 |clubs5 = [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] |caps5 = 2 |goals5 = 0 }} '''Robert Coltman Bolam''' (28 February 1896 – 1964) was an English [[association football|footballer]] who made 79 appearances in [[the Football League]] playing as an [[outside forward]], mainly at outside right, for [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]], [[South Shields F.C. (1889)|South Shields]] and [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref name=Joyce>{{cite book |last=Joyce |first=Michael |title=Football League Players' Records 1888 to 1939 |publisher=SoccerData |location=Nottingham |page=29 |year=2004 |isbn=978-1-899468-67-6}}</ref>
==Life and career== Bolam was the eighth of nine children of William Bolam, a general labourer, and his wife Margaret Agnes. He was born and raised in [[Birtley, County Durham]], and at the time of the 1911 Census, was working as a driver in a colliery.<ref name=1901Census>{{cite web |url=http://search.findmypast.co.uk/record?id=gbc/1901/0029787906 |subscription=yes |via=Findmypast |title=1901 England, Wales & Scotland Census Transcription 3, St Johns Place, Birtley, Chester Le Street, Durham, England |at=Robt Bolam. Age: 5. Birth place: Birtley Durham. Archive reference: RG13. Piece number: 4702. Folio: 107. Page: 33 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref><ref name=1911Census>{{cite web |url=http://search.findmypast.co.uk/record?id=gbc/1911/rg14/30123/0073/5 |subscription=yes |via=Findmypast |title=1911 England, Wales & Scotland Census Transcription 2 West Street Birtley, Birtley, Durham, England |at=Robert Cottman Bolam. Age: 15. Birth place: Birtley Durham. Occupation: Coal miner driver. Census reference: RG14PN30123 RG78PN1739 RD554 SD2 ED6 SN37 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> He served in the Royal Navy during the First World War.<ref name=WarService>{{cite web |url=http://search.findmypast.co.uk/record?id=gbm/adm188/269000 |title=Royal Navy Seamen 1899–1919 Transcription |subscription=yes |via=[[Findmypast]] |at=Robert Coltman Bolam. Service number: K41728. Birth date: 28 Feb 1896. Archive reference: ADM 188/950/41728 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
After the war, Bolam joined [[Football League First Division]] club [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]]. He made his debut in a 2–0 win against then league leaders, [[West Bromwich Albion]], in February 1920,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tamworthherald.co.uk/February-brings-mixed-fortunes-West-Bromwich/story-20538904-detail/story.html |title=February brings mixed fortunes for West Bromwich Albion |first=Ian |last=Edmunds |newspaper=Tamworth Herald |date=1 February 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> and in March, he scored, as well as creating several chances, in a 3–2 defeat at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in [[Charlie Buchan|Charles Buchan]]'s [[benefit match]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000276/19200317/080/0005 |title=Buchan's benefit |newspaper=Telegraph and Star |location=Sheffield |date=17 March 1920 |page=5 |subscription=yes |via=British Newspaper Archive}}</ref> According to the ''[[Sheffield Star|Telegraph and Star]]'', "he is speedy and invariably puts across a good ball, whilst his ability to use both feet enables him to meet his man with confidence and success".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000276/19200322/052/0003 |title=Football gossip |last='Free Lance' |newspaper=Telegraph and Star |location=Sheffield |date=22 March 1920 |page=3 |subscription=yes |via=British Newspaper Archive}}</ref> But he was unable to keep his place, and at the end of the 1921–22 season, was not included on the club's retained list, and signed for [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] of the [[Football League Third Division North|Third Division]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000324/19220708/065/0004 |title=Close season gossip |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=Hull |date=8 July 1922 |page=4 |subscription=yes |via=British Newspaper Archive |quote=When Sheffield United signed on R. C. Bolam, Birtley, two years ago it was thought they had got a first team man in the making. However, the Northerner only revealed his true form on odd occasions, and as United are now well served for extreme wing position, they have let him go to Darlington}}</ref>
He went straight into the starting eleven, and opened the scoring in a 4–0 defeat of [[Accrington Stanley F.C. (1891)|Accrington Stanley]] in his second match,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000511/19220904/013/0003 |title=Saturday's results |newspaper=Devon and Exeter Daily Gazette |date=4 September 1922 |page=3 |subscription=yes |via=British Newspaper Archive}}</ref> but soon lost his place,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000327/19230106/028/0004 |title=North and South. Bolam reappears |newspaper=Derby Daily Telegraph |date=6 January 1923 |page=4 |quote=He was dropped from the side last September, but reappeared a week ago to score a goal at Stalybridge. |subscription=yes |via=British Newspaper Archive}}</ref> played only 12 games over the season,<ref name=Joyce/> and moved on again, this time to [[South Shields F.C. (1889)|South Shields]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000324/19230808/007/0002 |title=Sporting items |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=Hull |date=8 August 1923 |page=2 |subscription=yes |via=British Newspaper Archive}}</ref> A match preview in the ''[[Derby Telegraph|Derby Daily Telegraph]]'' suggested his problem was temperamental: he "can play on either wing, and in the mood can be really dangerous, but he allows himself to become irritated, and goes off his game very easily."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000327/19240118/061/0006 |title=Derby's visitors |newspaper=Derby Daily Telegraph |date=18 January 1924 |page=6 |subscription=yes |via=British Newspaper Archive}}</ref> He began well for South Shields, with the only goal of the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] fixture against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000687/19230828/141/0003 |title=South Shields v. Blackpool |newspaper=Yorkshire Post |date=28 August 1923 |page=3 |subscription=yes |via=British Newspaper Archive}}</ref> and played regularly, making 32 league appearances,<ref name=Joyce/> but still left for yet another club at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000321/19240603/042/0008 |title=Sporting items |newspaper=Nottingham Evening Post |date=3 June 1924 |page=8 |subscription=yes |via=British Newspaper Archive}}</ref> He played twice in the [[Football League Third Division South|Third Division South]] for [[Queens Park Rangers]], and retired from football in the summer of 1925.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://qprnet.com/misc/seasonalstats/excels/QPR1925.xls |format=XLS |title=1925/26 |website=QPRnet.com |first=Kenneth |last=Westerberg |publisher=Ron Norris |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
Bolam returned to the north-east of England, where he had married Mary Nicholson in 1924.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://search.findmypast.co.uk/record?id=bmd/m/1924/3/az/000121/098 |subscription=yes |via=Findmypast |title=England & Wales marriages 1837–2008 Transcription |at=Robert C Bolam. District: Gateshead. County: Durham. Volume: 10A. Page: 1907 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> He died in 1964, aged 68, in [[Gateshead]].<ref name=deathcert>{{cite web |url=http://search.findmypast.co.uk/record?id=bmd/d/1964/2/az/000074/010 |subscription=yes |via=Findmypast |title=England & Wales deaths 1837–2007 Transcription |at=Robert C Bolam. Age: 68. District: Gateshead. County: Durham. Volume: 1A. Page: 778 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>

do not add a religious denomination here --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = <!-- may be used (optionally with father parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | father = <!-- may be used (optionally with mother parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | relatives = | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = | ethnicity = }}'''Bruno Jacquet Ossébi''', also known as Bruno Jacquet or Ossébi (December 10, 1964 – February 2, 2009), was a [[French people|Franco]]-[[Republic of the Congo|Congolese]] journalist for the online news site ''[[Mwinda]]''. Ossébi was working to expose government corruption when a mysterious fire broke out in his home. He sustained fatal injuries, and died in a military hospital in [[Brazzaville]], [[Republic of the Congo]] twelve days later.<ref name=theguardian>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2009/feb/12/africa-press-freedom1|title=Congo journalist dies after fire|first=Roy|last=Greenslade|date=12 February 2009|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref>
==Personal== Bruno Ossébi was born in [[France]], and originally given the name Bruno Jacquet. He was born on December 10, 1964 to a French father and a Congolese mother. He moved to the Republic of Congo in the early 1990s to pursue a career in blogging and journalism. He began writing for the Congolese web site ''Mwinda'' about hot-button political issues. Ossébi was thought to be protected as a French citizen, and cousin of several barons; however, he received several threats throughout his career.<ref name=lemonde>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2009/07/09/la-mort-mysterieuse-d-un-journaliste-franco-congolais-a-brazzaville_1217113_3212.html|title=La mort mystérieuse d'un journaliste franco-congolais à Brazzaville|date=9 July 2009|publisher=|via=Le Monde}}</ref> Ossébi was not married, but lived with his girlfriend and her two children. They also died in the house fire that killed Ossébi.<ref name=rsf>http://fr.rsf.org/congo-rapport-d-enquete-sur-la-mort-du-09-07-2009,33758.html</ref>
==Career== Ossébi was an activist throughout his career. He wrote for ''Mwinda'', and also created a personal blog (bruno-ossbi.novoblog.com). He began writing for ''Mwinda'' when President [[Denis Sassou-Nguesso]] came to power in the early 1990s. Ossébi sought to condemn the plundering of oil, timber, and violations of human rights in the Republic of Congo. He was also active in the StAR program of the [[World Bank]], and active with the [[United Nations]] program that recovers misappropriated African assets. Ossébi spent two years working with lawyers, activists, and citizens to develop a court complaint against President Sassou Nguesso, [[List of Presidents of Gabon|President of Gabon]] [[Omar Bongo]], and [[List of Presidents of Equatorial Guinea|President of Equatorial Guinea]] [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo|Teodoro Obiang]], accusing them of "misappropriation of public funds".<ref name=mediapart>{{cite web|url=https://www.mediapart.fr/journal/france/081208/plaintes-menaces-l-enquete-qui-affole-omar-bongo-et-d-autres-dirigeants-africa|title=Plaintes, menaces: l'enquête qui affole Omar Bongo et d'autres dirigeants africains|publisher=mediapart}}</ref>
==Death== <!--begin wikitable-->{{Location map+ |Republic of the Congo | relief = 1 | width = 200 | float = left | caption = Location of the place where he were killed in relation to the capital Brazzaville. | alt = Republic of the Congo map | position = right | mark = Red_pog.svg | marksize = 9 | places= {{Location map~|Republic of the Congo | lat_deg = 4 | lat_min = 16 | lat_sec = | lat_dir = S | lon_deg = 15 | lon_min = 17| lon_sec = | lon_dir = E | position = top | background = #CCCCCC | mark = Red pog.svg | label = Brazzaville}} }}<!--end wikitable-->On January 21, 2009, two fires broke out 6,000 km away from each other in two different Franco-Congolese journalist’s homes. Bruno Ossébi in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo, and Benjamin Toungamani in France. Both journalists, Ossébi included, were plaintiff’s in an “ill-gotten gains” complaint filed weeks before.<ref name=cpj1>{{cite web|url=https://cpj.org/2009/02/after-mysterious-fire-online-journalist-dead-in-re.php|title=After mysterious fire, online columnist dead in Congo - Committee to Protect Journalists|publisher=}}</ref> Ossébi and Toungamani both heavily criticized Denis Sassou Nguesso’s authoritarianism, and his lavish lifestyle at the expense of the Congolese people.<ref name=africatime>{{cite web|url=http://fr.africatime.com/congo/videos/la-mort-de-bruno-ossebi|title=La mort de Bruno Ossébi|publisher=}}</ref> Ossébi was able to escape the home, but died in a military hospital twelve days later.
There was no serious investigation or autopsy after the fires, according to [[Reporters Without Borders]].<ref name=afriquesenlutte>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriquesenlutte.org/afrique-centrale/congo-brazzaville/article/congo-brazzaville-il-faut-relancer|title=Afriques en Lutte|publisher=}}</ref> Bruno Ossébi’s official cause of death was “cardiac arrest”, and no mention of burns were notated, even though 30% of his body was covered.<ref name=cpj2>{{cite web|url=https://www.cpj.org/reports/2009/04/republic-of-congo-special-report-from-a-fatal-fire.php|title=Republic of Congo Special Report: From a Fatal Fire, Many Questions - Committee to Protect Journalists|publisher=}}</ref>
==Context== Three days before the fire broke out in Bruno Ossébi’s home, he published an article on ''Mwinda'' press. The article revealed that [[Société Nationale des Pétroles du Congo]], a petroleum company led by President Denis Sassou-Nguesso's son, [[Denis-Christel Sassou Nguesso]], was seeking a French bank loan of $100 million pledged to the production of oil.<ref name=hd>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oyMgIlcKuFkC&pg=PA340&lpg=PA340&dq=%22Bruno%20Oss%C3%A9bi%22&source=bl&ots=3fwBLw6Gdl&sig=Usn1SfsJO9VXJ4N_3TVyP0zUG7I&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwitjsGVvpDPAhXJ5yYKHchBDSoQ6AEIPzAE#v=onepage&q=%22Bruno%20Oss%C3%A9bi%22&f=false|title=Historical Dictionary of Republic of the Congo|last2=Decalo|first2=Samuel|date=9 August 2012|publisher=Scarecrow Press|first1=John F.|last1=Clark|via=Google Books}}</ref> Ossébi accused them of organizing a “debt front” which contradicted a commitment made by the Congo to the [[International Monetary Fund]]. Two days before the incident, Ossébi contacted the Committee to recover stolen property from the World Bank. A few weeks earlier, he had indicated his intention to join a complaint against “ill-gotten gains”.<ref name=lemonde />
==Impact== Following Ossébi’s death, Reporters Without Borders have accused officials of minimizing the case, and failing to carry out an official investigation or autopsy. Reporters Without Borders have since launched their own investigation into the case. More than 80 people have been interviewed including relatives, friends, other journalists, and government officials, but no further action has been taken. Reporters Without Borders continues to ask the French government for aid in solving the case.<ref name=congovision>{{cite web|url=http://www.congovision.com/nouvelles2/ossebi1.html|title=Congo Vision : Nouvelles visions pour le Congo et l'Afrique|publisher=congovision}}</ref>
==Reactions== [[Koïchiro Matsuura]], director-general of [[UNESCO]], said, "I deplore the death of Bruno Ossébi. I trust that the authorities will spare no effort in seeking to elucidate this tragedy as soon as possible. It is important to remember that the work of journalists is essential not only if we are to uphold the basic human right of freedom of expression but for democracy and good governance, issues that concern societies everywhere.” <ref name=unescoenglish>{{cite web|url=http://portal.unesco.org/ci/en/ev.php-URL_ID=28324&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html|title=Director-General deplores death of Congolese journalist Bruno Ossébi|publisher=UNESCO}}</ref><ref name=unescofrench>{{cite web|url=http://portal.unesco.org/ci/fr/ev.php-URL_ID=28324&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html|title=Le Directeur général déplore la mort du journaliste congolais Bruno Ossébi|publisher=UNESCO}}</ref>
Jean-François Julliard, former secretary-general of Reporters Without Borders, said, "Deploring the negligence of the investigation conducted in Brazzaville by the Congolese authorities, we asked the French government, six months after the death of Bruno Ossébi, to open an investigation in France." He adds, "Today, it is still unclear whether the fire in the journalist's home was accidental or criminal. We still do not know why Bruno Ossébi died suddenly, twelve days later, with his state of health. We are astonished that France has remained passive on the mysterious death of one of its nationals, recognized, moreover, as a very critical voice in a country that does not shine by its respect for the Freedom of the press."<ref name=fesmedia>{{cite web|url=http://www.fesmedia-africa.org/what-is-news/statements-developments/news/article/congo-il-faut-relancer-lenquete-sur-la-mort-du-journaliste-franco-congolais-bruno-ossebi/|title=Fesmedia Africa: Congo : "Il faut relancer l’enquête sur la mort du journaliste franco-congolais Bruno Ossébi"|first=fesmedia|last=Africa|publisher=fesmedia-africa}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Human rights in the Republic of the Congo]]

revision.text:
[[Cat]]s hunt small prey, and both [[feral cat|feral]] and [[domestication|domesticated]] cats prey on wildlife. This is sometimes seen as a desirable phenomenon, such as in the case of [[barn cat]]s and other cats kept for the purposes of pest control. As an invasive species<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sciencenordic.com/scientist-australia%E2%80%99s-feral-cats-should-be-eradicated |title=Scientist: Australia’s feral cats should be eradicated |last=Price Persson |first=Charlotte |date=26 November 2017 |website=ScienceNordic}}</ref> and superpredator,<ref name="Nogales"/> they do considerable ecological damage.<ref name="Nogales"/> In Australia, hunting by cats helped to drive at least 20 native mammals to extinction,<ref name="Feral Cats FAQ">{{cite web|title=Tackling Feral Cats and Their Impacts - Frequently asked questions|url=https://www.environment.gov.au/system/files/resources/bb591b82-1699-4660-8e75-6f5612b21d5f/files/factsheet-tackling-feral-cats-and-their-impacts-faqs.pdf|website=Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy|accessdate=12 May 2018}}</ref> and continues to threaten at least 124 more.<ref name="Feral Cats FAQ"/> Their introduction has caused the extinction of at least 33 endemic species on islands throughout the world.<ref name="Nogales">{{cite journal|last1=Nogales|first1=Manuel|last2=Vidal|first2=Eric|last3=et. al.|title=Feral Cats and Biodiversity Conservation: The Urgent Prioritization of Island Management|journal=BioScience|date=1 October 2013|volume=63|issue=10|pages=804–810|url=https://academic.oup.com/bioscience/article/63/10/804/238142|accessdate=12 May 2018|doi=10.1525/bio.2013.63.10.7}}</ref> Feral and domestic cats kill billions of birds in the United States every year, where songbird populations continue to decline.<ref name="Loss 2013"/>
[[File:Feral Cat (5573630708).jpg|thumb|right|Cats kill billions of wild birds each year. This feral cat near [[Brisbane]] has caught a [[budgerigar]]. ]]
==Mice and rats== For thousands of years, cats have been known for their ability to hunt mice and rats and keep their populations under control. This ability is understood as the reason cats became domesticated.<ref name="Temple Grandin">Grandin, Temple and Johnson, Catherine (2009) ''Animals Make Us Human: Creating the Best Life for Animals'', Mariner Books, {{ISBN|9780151014897}}.</ref> {{rp|68}} The relationship was more of convenience (or mutualistic) than dependence: "Cats killed mice and rats, and humans provided lots of mice and rats to kill since mice and rats lived in human settlements."<ref name="Temple Grandin"/>{{rp|68}} A 2014 study examining 5,300 years of cat remains in an agricultural village of Quanhucun, [[China]], provides early evidence of this dynamic, where cats protected grain stores by eating rodents.<ref name="Ancient cat bones">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/dec/17/ancient-cat-bone-research-china-domestic-pet | title=Ancient Chinese cat bones shake up domestication theory | newspaper=The Guardian | date=17 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="Hu 2014 on Cat domestication"> {{cite journal|doi= 10.1073/pnas.1311439110|title= Earliest evidence for commensal processes of cat domestication|journal= Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume= 111|pages= 116–120|year= 2013|last1= Hu|first1= Y.|last2= Hu|first2= S.|last3= Wang|first3= W.|last4= Wu|first4= X.|last5= Marshall|first5= F. B.|last6= Chen|first6= X.|last7= Hou|first7= L.|last8= Wang|first8= C.|pmid=24344279|pmc=3890806}}</ref>
If they are well-fed, [[farm cat]]s are more dependable as effective ratters, as they are less likely to stray or hunt further afield.<ref name="Tabor Wild Life">Tabor, Roger (1983) ''The Wild Life of the Domestic Cat''. Arrow Books. {{ISBN|0099312107}}.</ref>{{rp|110}} Cats are wary of adult rats, given their size,<ref name="Tabor Wild Life"/>{{rp|111}} but are particularly adept at hunting young rats.<ref name="Tabor Wild Life"/>{{rp|110}}
In 2002, feral cats introduced to a flower market in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], were noted to have helped lower rat populations.<ref name="Beverly Hills Rats">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/17/us/up-down-in-and-out-in-beverly-hills-rats.html | title=Up, Down, In and Out in Beverly Hills: Rats | first=Charlie | last=LeDuff | newspaper=The New York Times | date=17 September 2002}}</ref> In [[Chicago]]'s 47th Ward, feral cats were introduced in 2012 to help the city deal with the rat problem there.<ref>[http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2012/06/28/north-sides-47th-ward-using-feral-cats-to-catch-rats/ "North Side’s 47th Ward Using Feral Cats To Catch Rats"], CBS Chicago, 28 June 2012.</ref>
Efforts to eradicate feral cats in [[Ventura, California]], were noted in 2002 to have resulted in increasing numbers of rats, which were being monitored for health problems such as [[bubonic plague]].<ref name="Beverly Hills Rats"/><ref name="LA rodents have field day">{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/sep/09/local/me-rats9 | title=With the Cats Away, Beachfront Rodents Have a Field Day | first=Jessica | last=Blanchard | newspaper=Los Angeles Times | date=9 September 2002}}</ref>
==Birds== A 2013 study by Scott R. Loss and others of the [[Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute]] and the [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service|U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service]] suggested that free-ranging domestic cats (mostly unowned) are the top human-caused threat to wildlife in the United States, killing an estimated 1.3 to 4 billion birds and 6.3 to 22.3 billion mammals annually.<ref name="Loss 2013">{{cite journal|url=http://www.alleycat.org/document.doc?id=634|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904132317/http://www.alleycat.org/document.doc?id=634|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-09-04|title=The impact of free-ranging domestic cats on wildlife of the United States|journal=Nature Communications|volume=4|pages=1396|doi=10.1038/ncomms2380|pmid=23360987|year=2013|last1=Loss|first1=Scott R.|last2=Will|first2=Tom|last3=Marra|first3=Peter P.}}</ref><ref name='BBCNews'>{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21236690 | title = Cats killing billions of animals in the US | accessdate = 12 February 2013 | last = Morelle | first = Rebecca | date = 29 January 2013 | work = BBC News}}</ref> These figures were much higher than previous estimates for the U.S.<ref name="Loss 2013"/>{{rp|2}} Unspecified species of birds native to the U.S. and mammals including [[mouse|mice]], [[shrew]]s, [[vole]]s, [[squirrel]]s and [[rabbit]]s were considered most likely to be preyed upon by cats.<ref name="Loss 2013"/>{{rp|4}}
Perhaps the first U.S. study that pointed to predation by cats on wildlife as a concern was ornithologist [[Edward Howe Forbush]]'s 1916 report for the Massachusetts State Board of Agriculture, ''The Domestic Cat: Bird Killer, Mouser and Destroyer of Wildlife: Means of Utilizing and Controlling It''.<ref>Edward Howe Forbush, [https://archive.org/details/domesticcatbirdk00forbrich "The Domestic Cat: Bird Killer, Mouser and Destroyer of Wildlife: Means of Utilizing and Controlling It"], Commonwealth of Massachusetts, State Board of Agriculture, Economic Biology Bulletin 42, 1916.</ref>
[[File:... The domestic cat; bird killer, mouser and destroyer of wild life; means of utilizing and controlling it (1916) (20998811541).jpg|thumb|A feral cat with an [[American Robin]]. Plate from Forbush (1916).]]
U.K. biologist and cat behaviour expert Roger Tabor states that "studies from all around the world have found that cats catch relatively few birds compared to small mammals."<ref name="Tabor Cat Behavior">Tabor, Roger (2003) ''Understanding Cat Behavior''. David & Charles Ltd. {{ISBN|9780715315897}}.</ref>{{rp|135}} The [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] states that there is no scientific evidence that cat predation "is having any impact on bird populations UK-wide."<ref name="Are cats causing bird declines?"> [http://www.rspb.org.uk/advice/gardening/unwantedvisitors/cats/birddeclines.aspx "Are cats causing bird declines?"] The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, accessed 23 June 2014.</ref> Moreover, city cats have smaller ranges. In his research, Tabor found "the average annual catch of the average London cat to be two items instead of the fourteen of a village cat."<ref name="Tabor Cat Behavior"/>{{rp|135}} Tabor comments about some of the challenges of stalking birds for cats: "From the cat's point of view not only do birds not play fair by flying and having eyes that can see beyond the back of their heads, but they can positively cheat by using loud alarm calls and throw the cat's chances of catching any others."<ref name="Tabor Wild Life"/>{{rp|123}}
Island settings pose particular challenges for wildlife. A 2001 study identified cats alone as responsible for the plight of some island bird species, such as the [[Townsend's shearwater]], [[socorro dove]], and the [[Marquesan ground dove]].<ref name="Endangered birds"> {{cite book|last=Collar|first=N. J.|title=Endangered Birds|url=http://people.ds.cam.ac.uk/cns26/NJC/Papers/Endangered_birds.pdf |volume=2|year=2001|publisher=Academic Press|location=New York|page=400}} in ''Encyclopedia of Biodiversity''</ref><ref name="Endangered birds"/>{{rp|400}} The same study identified the greatest cause of endangerment of birds as habitat loss and degradation, with at least 52% of endangered birds affected,<ref name="Endangered birds"/>{{rp|399}} while [[introduced species]] on islands, such as domestic cats, [[rat]]s and [[Mustelidae|mustelids]],<ref name="Endangered birds"/>{{rp|403}} affected only 6% of endangered birds.<ref name="Endangered birds"/>{{rp|399}} Other studies caution that removing domestic cats from islands can have unintended consequences, as increasing rat populations can put native bird<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 15998496 | doi=10.1016/j.bulm.2004.12.002 | volume=67 | issue=5 | title=Cats protecting birds revisited | journal=Bull Math Biol | pages=1081–106 | last1 = Fan | first1 = M | last2 = Kuang | first2 = Y | last3 = Feng | first3 = Z |date=September 2005}}</ref> and mammal species<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hanna | first1 = Emily | display-authors = etal | date = April 2014 | title = Island mammal extinctions are determined by interactive effects of life history, island biogeography and mesopredator suppression | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/geb.12103/abstract | journal = Global Ecology and Biogeography | volume = 23| issue = 4 | pages = 395–404| doi=10.1111/geb.12103}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/conservation/feral-cats-help-some-endangered-mammals-survive-report-says-20130829-2ssvt.html | title=Feral cats help some endangered mammals survive, report says | first=Gerald | last=Popkin | newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald | date=29 August 2013}}</ref> at risk.
==Impact by location==
===Australia=== {{See also|Cats in Australia}}
Cats in Australia have been found to have European origins.<ref>{{Cite journal |title = The Population Origins and Expansion of Feral Cats in Australia |last = Spencer |first = Peter B.S. |last2=Yurchenko |first2=Andrey A. |last3=David |first3=Victor A. |last4=Scott |first4=Rachael |last5=Koepfli |first5=Klaus-Peter |last6=Driscoll |first6=Carlos |last7=O’Brien |first7=Stephen J. |last8=Menotti-Raymond |first8=Marilyn |date = 9 November 2015 |journal=Journal of Heredity |publisher = American Genetic Association |doi = 10.1093/jhered/esv095 |volume=107 |issue=2 |pages=104–114 |pmc=4757960 |pmid=26647063}}</ref> This is important to note because of their effect on native species. Feral cats in Australia have been linked to the decline and extinction of various native animals. They have been shown to cause a significant impact on ground nesting birds and small native mammals.<ref name="Dickman">{{cite book|last1 = Dickman|first1 = Chris|title = Overview of the Impacts of Feral Cats on Australian Native Fauna|publisher = The Director of National Parks and Wildlife – Australian Nature Conservation Agency – Institute of Wildlife Research|date = May 1996|url = http://secure.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/pubs/impacts-feral-cats.pdf|accessdate = 11 February 2013|isbn = 0-642-21379-8|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304040904/http://secure.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/pubs/impacts-feral-cats.pdf|archivedate = 4 March 2016|df = }}</ref>
Feral cats have also hampered any attempts to re-introduce threatened species back into areas where they have become extinct as the cats have hunted and killed the newly released animals.<ref>[http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/pestsweeds/TheThreatOfFeralCats.htm The Threat Of Feral Cats]. Environment.nsw.gov.au (28 October 2011). Retrieved on 5 May 2013.</ref> Numerous Australian environmentalists claim the feral cat has been an ecological disaster in Australia, inhabiting most ecosystems except dense [[rainforest]], and being implicated in the [[extinction]] of several [[marsupial]] and [[Placentalia|placental]] mammal [[species]].<ref name="Interactions">{{cite journal | title = Interactions between feral cats, foxes, native carnivores, and rabbits in Australia | journal = CSIRO Sustainable Ecosystems / Arthur Rylah Institute for Environmental Research | date = Sep 2004 | author = Robley, A. | author2 = Reddiex, B. | author3 = Arthur, T. | author4 = Pech, R. | author5 = Forsyth, D. | url = http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/pubs/interaction.pdf | accessdate = 12 February 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317105943/http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/pubs/interaction.pdf|archivedate=17 March 2011}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== {{See also|Cats in New Zealand}}
The fauna of [[New Zealand]] has evolved in isolation for millions of years without the presence of mammals (apart from a few bat species). Consequently, birds dominated the niches occupied by mammals and many became flightless. The introduction of mammals after settlement by [[Māori people|Māori]] from about the 12th century had a huge effect on the indigenous [[biodiversity]]. [[Europe]]an explorers and settlers brought cats on their ships and the presence of feral cats were recorded from the latter decades of the 19th century.<ref>King, Carolyn (1984) ''Immigrant Killers''. Auckland: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-558121-0}}</ref> It is estimated that feral cats have been responsible for the extinction of six endemic bird species and over 70 localised subspecies as well as depleting bird and lizard species.<ref>{{Cite conference | author = Eason, Charles T. | author2 = Morgan, David R. | author3 = Clapperton, B. Kay | last-author-amp = yes | title = Toxic bait and baiting strategies for feral cats | publisher = Proceedings of the Fifteenth Vertebrate Pest Conference 1992 | year = 1992 | location = University of Nebraska – Lincoln | url = http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1024&context=vpc15}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In the [[United Kingdom|U.K.]], The [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] states that there is no scientific evidence that cat predation "is having any impact on bird populations UK-wide. The article goes on to say, "This may be surprising, but many millions of birds die naturally every year, mainly through starvation, disease, or other forms of predation. There is evidence that cats tend to take weak or sickly birds".
"Those bird species that have undergone the most serious population declines in the UK (such as [[Alauda|skylarks]], [[Eurasian tree sparrow|tree sparrows]] and [[corn bunting]]s) rarely encounter cats, so cats cannot be causing their declines. Research shows that these declines are usually caused by habitat change or loss, particularly on farmland."<ref name="Are cats causing bird declines?"/> This evidence is despite the common practice in the U.K. of allowing owned cats access to the outdoors,<ref>"In the UK, the vast majority of pet cats have free access to the outside world, or are at least allowed to go outside unsupervised for large parts of the day." [http://www.pets4homes.co.uk/pet-advice/a-world-of-difference-how-cat-ownership-in-america-differs-to-the-uk.html "A world of difference – How cat ownership in America differs to the UK"], Pets4Homes, accessed 1 September 2014.</ref> which is recommended to prevent feline obesity (p. 138) and behavior problems and other health problems arising from confinement stress (p. 121).<ref name="Tabor Cat Behavior"/>
[[SongBird Survival]] considers that "The prevailing line that "there is no scientific evidence that predation by cats is having any impact on bird populations in UK" is simply no longer tenable",<ref>https://www.songbird-survival.org.uk/cats.html</ref> noting "No study has ever examined the impact of cats on songbirds at the population level; Evidence shows that the recovering sparrowhawk population in the 1970-80s resulted in the decline of some songbird populations; Cats kill around 3 times as many songbirds as sparrowhawks; The mere presence of cats near birds' nests was found to decrease provision of food by a third while the resultant mobbing clamour from parent birds led in turn to increased nest predation by crows and magpies; [and that] It is therefore far more likely that cats have an even greater impact on songbird populations than sparrowhawks."
[[Sir David Attenborough]] in his Christmas Day edition of [[BBC Radio 4]] programme Tweet Of The Day said ""Cats kill an extraordinarily high number of birds in British gardens".<ref>{{cite news |date=10 December 2013 |title=Cats killing huge numbers of British birds, Sir David Attenborough warns |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/dec/10/cats-killing-birds-gardens-david-attenborough |work=The Guardian}}</ref> Asked whether cat owners should buy bell collars for their pets at Christmas, he replied: "That would be good for the robins, yes."
===Islands===
====Consequences of introduction==== [[File:Xenicus lyalli.jpg|right|thumb|[[Lyall's wren]] became extinct within two years of the introduction of cats to [[Stephens Island, New Zealand|Stephens Island]].]]
Many islands host [[island tameness|ecologically naive]] animal species. That is, animals that do not have predator responses for dealing with predators such as cats.<ref name="Moors">Moors, P.J.; Atkinson, I.A.E. (1984). "Predation on seabirds by introduced animals, and factors affecting its severity" in ''Status and Conservation of the World's Seabirds''. Cambridge: ICBP. {{ISBN|0-946888-03-5}}.</ref> Feral cats [[introduced species|introduced]] to such islands have had a devastating impact on these islands' [[biodiversity]].<ref name="NYT"/>
They have been implicated in the extinction of several species and local extinctions, such as the [[hutia]]s from the [[Caribbean]], the [[Guadalupe storm petrel]] from the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] coast of [[Mexico]], and [[Lyall's wren]]. In a statistical study, they were a significant cause for the extinction of 40% of the species studied.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/02/magazine/02cats-v--birds-t.html?em&ex=1196830800&en=4328122ab745ee4d&ei=5087%0A | work=The New York Times | title=Kill the Cat That Kills the Bird? | first=Bruce | last=Barcott | date=2 December 2007}}</ref> Moors and Atkinson wrote, in 1984, "No other alien predator has had such a universally damaging effect."<ref name="Moors"/>
Feral cats, along with rabbits, some sea birds, and [[sheep]], form the entire large animal population of the remote [[Kerguelen Islands]] in the southern [[Indian Ocean]]. Although exotic mammals form the bulk of their diet, cats' impact on seabirds is very important.<ref name="Kerguelen">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s00300-002-0424-5 | title=The diet of feral cats (''Felis catus'' L.) at five sites on the Grande Terre, Kerguelen archipelago | author=Pontier, D. | author2=E. Natoli | author3=L. Say | author4=F. Debias | author5=J. Bried | author6=J. Thioulouse | author7=T. Micol | author8=E. Natoli | last-author-amp=yes|url=http://pbil.univ-lyon1.fr/JTHome/ref/DPetal2002.pdf | year=2002 | journal=Polar Biology | volume=25 | issue=11 | pages=833–837}}</ref>
====Restoration==== Because of the damage cats cause in islands and some ecosystems, many conservationists working in the field of [[island restoration]] have worked to remove feral cats. (Island restoration involves the removal of introduced species and reintroducing native species.) {{as of|2004}}, 48 islands have had their feral cat populations eradicated, including [[New Zealand]]'s network of offshore island bird reserves<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.issg.org/pdf/publications/Island_Invasives/pdfHQprint/1Campbell.pdf|title=A review of feral cat eradication on islands|doi=10.1111/j.1523-1739.2004.00442.x|year=2004|last1=Nogales|first1=Manuel|last2=Martin|first2=Aurelio|last3=Tershy|first3=Bernie R.|last4=Donlan|first4=C. Josh|last5=Veitch|first5=Dick|last6=Puerta|first6=Nestor|last7=Wood|first7=Bill|last8=Alonso|first8=Jesus|journal=Conservation Biology|volume=18|issue=2|pages=310–319}}</ref> and Australia's [[Macquarie Island]].
Larger projects have also been undertaken, including their complete removal from [[Ascension Island]]. The cats, introduced in the 19th century, caused a collapse in populations of nesting [[seabird]]s. The project to remove them from the island began in 2002, and the island was cleared of cats by 2004. Since then, seven species of seabird that had not nested on the island for 100 years have returned.<ref>[http://petsaspests.blogspot.com/search?q=ascension Cat eradication from Ascension Island]. Petsaspests.blogspot.com (2014-01-23). Retrieved on 2015-11-01.</ref>
In some cases, the removal of cats had [[unintended consequences]]. An example is Macquarie Island, where the removal of cats caused an explosion in the number of rabbits, rats, and mice that harm native seabirds<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/environment/up-against-rats-rabbits-and-costs/2007/04/11/1175971183257.html?page=fullpage | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Up against rats, rabbits and costs | date=12 April 2007}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060720104709/http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200607/s1687413.htm Fears for sub-antarctic island plagued by rabbits]. ABC News (15 July 2006).</ref><ref>Draper, Michelle and La Canna, Xavier (14 January 2009) [https://web.archive.org/web/20110706111235/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=718505 Cat kill devastates Macquarie Island]. Nine News</ref> even if the eradication was positioned within an integrated pest management framework.<ref>[http://petsaspests.blogspot.com.es/2013/05/controversy-on-cats-eradication-on.html Controversy on feral cat removal on Macquarie Island]. Petsaspests.blogspot.com.es (2013-05-14). Retrieved on 2015-11-01.</ref> The removal of the rats and rabbits was scheduled for 2007 and it could take up to seven years and cost $24 million.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070812004625/http://www.parks.tas.gov.au/macquarie/rabbitsfaq.html Macquarie Island World Heritage Area. Plan for the Eradication of Rabbits and Rodents on Macquarie Island]. Parks and Wildlife Service, Tasmania. parks.tas.gov.au</ref>

[[File:chegong.JPG|thumb|upright|Statue of Che Kung inside the [[Tin Hau temples in Hong Kong|Tin Hau temple]] at [[Stanley, Hong Kong|Stanley]], [[Hong Kong]].]]
'''Che Kung''' ({{zh|t=車公|p=Chēgōng|l=Lord Che}}), also known as '''Che Da Yuan Shuai''' ({{zh|t=車大元帥|l=Che, the Great Warrior|labels=no}}) was originally a military commander of [[Southern Song Dynasty]] (1127–1279), who, according to lore, had supreme power to suppress rebellion and was renowned for his loyalty to the Emperor.<ref name="Grade II">[http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/ce/Museum/Monument/form/Brief_Information_on_proposed_Grade_II_Items.pdf Brief Information on Proposed Grade II Items. pp656-657] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130223210048/http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/CE/Museum/Monument/form/Brief_Information_on_proposed_Grade_II_Items.pdf |date=2013-02-23 }}</ref> He was also famous for his power to suppress plagues and his skill in medicine.<ref name="Grade I">[http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/ce/Museum/Monument/form/Brief_Information_on_proposed_Grade_I_Items.pdf Brief Information on Proposed Grade I Items. pp67-68] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013023413/http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/ce/Museum/Monument/form/Brief_Information_on_proposed_Grade_I_Items.pdf |date=October 13, 2012 }}</ref> He is believed by some worshipers to have been involved in the attempt to keep the Song state alive by bringing [[Emperor Bing of Song|Prince Ping]] and [[Emperor Duanzong of Song|his brother]] to the South.<ref>[http://www.epd.gov.hk/eia/register/report/eiareport/eia_1012004/eia_report/pdf/Volume%201/app_10.4.PDF The Historical Heritage of Ho Chung, Pak Kong, and Sha Kok Mei, Sai Kung. p5]</ref> He is now considered a god of protection.
==Life== [[Image:HK Ho Chung Che Kung Temple front.JPG|right|thumb|A Che Kung Temple in [[Ho Chung]], [[Sai Kung]], [[Hong Kong]].]] Che Kung was a native of [[Nanchang]], in [[Jiangxi]] Province of [[China]].<ref name="Grade II" /> As a military commander he saved the southern regions of China from disorder. Also, he appeared in the villagers dreams who suffered from a plague. Later on, the plague was over and the villagers thought that Che Kung saved them from diseases. [[Daoism|Daoists]] regarded him as a god due to his contributions. Inside a temple of Che Kung, [[Pinwheel (toy)|pinwheels]] can always be found next to his effigy. It is believed that the one who rotates the pinwheel can get good luck. [[The Birthday of Che Kung]] is celebrated on the second day of Chinese New Year.
